title: Artificial Neural Network writes Harry Potter and the Methods of Rationality

text:
You’ve spotted that items online, you love it and want it, but you don’t know how to find it in a store and buy it? To even worsen matter, you find it hard describing what you saw. Well, the solution to a problem like this is now– visual search.

There is a myriad of apps out there capturing the visual search technology space. With this innovatory development, I think it’s safe to say that the days of traditional text-based search may well be numbered. Or, am I just wishing…?

Well, that said, I’ll share with you four of those clever apps:

Pinterest Visual search: I discovered this feature rather accidentally, whilst trying to pin an item. For me, this is the icing on the cake of Pinterest’s already clean and chic interface. By tapping on the tiny visual search button on the image and hovering over the image, a selection of recommended visually-similar items is returned.

Also coming in the next few months is a new camera-search technology. Powered by deep learning technology, pinners will be able to trigger the visual search button and Pinterest would match the item against those in its enormous database, and link the pinner to the sites where they can buy the item searched.

Pinterest is available on Google Play and in AppStore.

Firefly: While this is not new-on- the- block per se, but I always get a totally different and (of course) better experience on my Amazon shopping anytime I get to use it. Note, “Amazon shopping”. Firefly is not standalone app, it works within the Amazon app and aside it’s main purpose of searching for products on Amazon, it can also recognise music, movies — even an artwork. With image-recogniti­­on technology , Firefly detects QR codes and bar codes on an item, and then uses the data gathered in locating products in their vast database.

Craves: Craves app takes fashion and online shopping experience up to a whole new dimension. We often find QR codes scanning a little unwieldy, but Crave takes away the strain of scanning a QR code to make a purchase. By simply pointing to the item you like in real life and taking a snapshot of it, Craves searches online across many retailers’ sites and returns the exact item, giving you the option to purchase right there within the platform.

An added feature to it is the collaborative and social element, which makes it possible to connect with friends, see trending items and be informed first hand on offers and deals — yeah, before they sell out!

Craves is available on Google Play and in AppStore.

CamFind: Launched a few years ago, CamFind uses a mobile visual technology, and powered by Cloudsight API, it can identify any object in an existing photograph or from a snapshot taken from a mobile device, and return an accurate result instantly.

Like Crave, there is a social feature for connecting with friends. And where you are searching a product, it checks across a range of online shopping sites and compares prices too.

CamFind is on Google Play and in AppStore.

Do you know of any other visual search app you think we should know about? Please share.
title: 4 Ways To Search For Products Using Your Phone Camera
